column127: Yes, during implementation we request our client’s taxation stance where it applies, based on their benefit plan design. The IRS provides limited guidance and how/whether certain covered services should be taxed (i.e. whether the procedure is elective, which means it may be taxable, or medically necessary, which means it may be tax deductible). The Plan Sponsor is responsible for determining the tax treatment of fertility preservation, donor tissue purchase, and imputing taxable income (including adoption and surrogacy reimbursement), and we can administer their benefit according to their decision.     We encourage our clients to confer with their ERISA counsel regarding any tax implications for fertility preservation and donor tissue purchase. While the majority of our clients treat these services on pre-tax basis, if treated on a post-tax basis then we are able to administratively support. Progyny will provide member-level claims reporting on all taxable deemed services to a dedicated contact with the client so that they can impute income as they deem appropriate.

column40: Boram Care is the first company in the US to offer a holistic approach to postpartum care. We have dedicated postnatal retreats for mothers as well as virtual postnatal coaches to help families navigate postpartum.   The US currently ranks first in maternal mortality within the OECD countries, third in infant mortality and 1 in 5 moms meet the criteria for major depressive disorders. This is the problem we are addressing and it’d be great to have a like minded partner.
column42: we do not have headcount minimums
column43: Our current model is utilization based. Companies pay for employee based on level of service:  3 night retreat stay + 3 month virtual coaching: $3,750  3 month virtual coaching: $1,050 includes: 7AM-7PM text support, one-on-one zoom sessions (lactation support, sleep training, etc), access to educational videos and access to community
column54: 7AM - 7PM EST
column55: At Boram, we define and approach customer service with a deep commitment to the well-being and satisfaction of our guests - new mothers and their newborn babies. Our philosophy revolves around the understanding that the postpartum period is a crucial time for both the mother and the newborn, and we aim to provide unparalleled support during this significant phase.  Personalized Care: we recognize that every mother is unique, and their needs may vary. Our customer service is built on the foundation of personalized care, tailoring our services to meet the specific requirements of each guest.  Judgement Free: we embrace a non-judgmental ethos, providing unwavering support and care to every mother on her unique postpartum journey. Motherhood is a transformative journey, and we approach our clients with empathy and understanding. We listen attentively to their concerns, offering emotional support along with practical solutions.  Accessibility: our commitment to "come through" for our guests means we prioritize accessibility. Whether it's a question in the middle of the night or a concern that requires immediate attention, our clients can rely on us to be there when they need us. We have hosted parents who are visually impaired as well as physically disabled.   Expertise and Professionalism: we take pride in maintaining a team of experienced and compassionate professionals. Our staff is trained to provide expert care, ensuring that our clients receive the highest standard of service.  In summary, at Boram, customer service goes beyond meeting basic needs; it's about providing comprehensive, compassionate, and personalized care to support mothers during the transformative postpartum period. Our dedication to coming through for our clients, no matter what, is the driving force behind our commitment to excellence in postpartum care.
column56: All leadership in our team are Registered Nurses with over 10 years in Labor and Delivery or NICU experience. They are also certified IBCLCs (International Board of Lactation Consultant). Our Care Associates are composed of Certified Nurse Assistants and Postpartum Doulas who have undergone Boram's backgroud and reference checks as well as our training program (didactic and in-situ)  Our virtual coaching staff is lead by a certified lactation counselor with a certificate in perinatal mental health and a masters in clinical psychology. Her team is trained in-house.
column67: We take in employers on a rolling basis through the year as our model is utilization based.   Once an employer decides to offer Boram Care benefits to their employees, we create a landing page for the employees where they can book their stay or subscribe to our virtual postpartum service. Once reservations are made, we notify the employer for approval and payment.
column74: We provide employers with our email template they can use to disseminate to their employees, including a link to the landing page. If employer has a benefits page, our team will populate with the necessary descriptions.   For example, Amazon has been featuring us in their NYC internal emails and HR site for our retreat services. In March 2024 Boram is slated to be featured in Amazon's internal newsletter to bring awareness of our virtual postnatal services to Amazonians who are outside of NYC.
column79: At Boram we support Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) both internally and externally by implementing intentional strategies that foster a more inclusive and supportive environment for individuals from diverse backgrounds.  INTERNALLY  Diverse Staff Representation: we ensure a diverse representation among staff members to reflect the varied experiences of the clients. This includes hiring individuals from different cultural and ethnic backgrounds as well as gender identities.  Culturally Competent Care: we train staff to be culturally competent and sensitive to the diverse needs of mothers from various backgrounds without judgment. This includes understanding cultural practices related to postpartum care and adapting services accordingly.  Ongoing Diversity Training: we conduct regular diversity training for all staff members to raise awareness about unconscious biases, cultural competence, and the importance of creating an inclusive environment.  EXTERNALLY  Tailored Services: customize postpartum services to be inclusive of diverse cultural practices, dietary needs, and family structures. This may involve collaborating with cultural experts or consultants.  Multilingual Support: we offer support in multiple languages to ensure effective communication and accessibility for clients who may speak languages other than the dominant one in the region.  Cultural Competence Education: we provide educational resources to clients about the importance of cultural competence in postpartum care. This can include workshops, informational materials, or online resources.  Community Engagement: we actively engage with and contribute to diverse communities. This may involve participating in community events, collaborating with local organizations, and supporting initiatives that promote health and well-being within diverse populations. We are also working with non-profit organizations to sponsor at risk mothers during their early postpartum period to ensure they have access to guidance and resources to recover.
column81: none
column92: We provide immediate booking of services by employees for employer approval. These reports can also be scheduled on a monthly basis.
column101: EPDS screening: Edinburgh Postpartum Depression Scale evaluates a mother's mental health during the postpartum period. We administer the EPDS survey at three month intervals to ensure the mom's mental health and take action when numbers exceed a threshold.   Lactation support: our trained staff assist mothers during the first few weeks for breastfeeding - this is one of the most requested services onsite and with our virtual coaches. We cover everything from latching to feeding plans.   Readiness to return to work: around the three-month mark, our clients engage with our coaches to discuss their preparedness for returning to work, facilitating a seamless transition and ensuring a successful reintegration into the workplace  Baby Care: from expert guidance on sleep training to navigating the introduction of solids, our coaches empower mothers with comprehensive support, ensuring they confidently and effectively plan and execute essential aspects of baby care for optimal parenting

column117: Here are steps we take to assist clients in maintaining compliance:  Understand Applicable Laws: we familiarize ourselves with federal, state, and local laws related to postpartum benefits and stay informed about any changes or updates in regulations that may impact the compliance of your services.  Provide Compliance Information: we offer clients clear and comprehensive information about the tax implications and compliance requirements associated with the educational benefits we provide. This may include detailing which aspects of the program are taxable and any reporting obligations.  Document Program Details: we collaborate with clients to document the specifics of the postpartum benefits program. Clearly outline eligibility criteria, covered expenses, and any limitations. Having a well-documented program helps in maintaining consistency and compliance.  Implement Reporting and Record-Keeping Tools: we integrate reporting and record-keeping tools into your services to help your client track and document relevant details. This facilitates compliance with reporting requirements and audits.

column33: Color Overview - Cancer Prevention and Screening Program  - For Brokers and Consultants.pdf
column40: Screening adherence gaps exist because access to services remains a challenge — guidelines change, people don’t know what screenings they need or when to complete them, they don’t know how to access care, they’re afraid, they can’t find a doctor, they don’t have time to go to a PCP then a specialist, or they’re deterred by co-pays, unexpected fees, or deductibles. Color’s programs addresses these gaps. In our experience, the following elements have been essential for the development of our successful wellness program:  Color offers distributed screenings and full-touch support that gets participants to adhere to screening guidelines. Our program solves for convenient screening experience first - by offering no-cost, at-home screens for cardiometabolic disease, colorectal, cervical, and prostate cancer; by finding and scheduling appointments with in-network, available providers and screening centers on behalf of members; by providing a care team of clinicians and care advocates that are available outside of working hours, and more. By removing the barriers associated with accessing screenings and preventive care, we drive far higher adherence to screening recommendations than health plans.  Color provides the only comprehensive solution in the market that tackles cardiac disease and cancer costs from screening through diagnosis and care. By the time someone has a late-stage cancer diagnosis or advanced heart disease, it’s unfortunately often too late to impact outcomes and the total cost of treatment. That’s why our program focuses on screening and prevention. Beginning with a risk assessment which is a combination of family history, patient-reported outcomes, and environmental factors that drives eligibility parameters to determine the appropriate screening. Followed by a personalized care plan with appropriate screenings. We don’t stop there - as we know that it’s essential that those with an abnormal screen result get seen for prompt follow-up, and in the event of a diagnosis, we offer the support and resources needed to navigate their health.  Our accessible approach drives high participation and engagement. Through nearly 10 years of learned experience providing preventive care programs, we’ve developed an approach to access and engagement that drives results - seeing increased utilization with Color versus the other wellness programs. It starts with a simple, easy, and convenient participant-facing experience including, support in 200+ languages, clinician availability outside of working hours, and access to screening services at home or onsite. We tailor communications and enrollment messaging to resonate with participants, building trust from day one.   Our program is affordable, because our service delivery is highly efficient. When healthcare is delivered outside of the walls of hospitals and clinics, we’re able to drive down the costs that impact our customers and participants. As examples our tests for cervical, colorectal, and prostate cancer are designed to be self-administered. We offer efficient virtual clinical interactions via messaging, phone, and video, and we collapse the number of healthcare interactions needed by streamlining all referral, preauthorization, and follow-up needs into fewer events. Additionally, our team of highly experienced care advocates helps participants direct to in-person screening for breast and lung cancer screening, understand the costs of follow-on in-person care to avoid surprise bills and navigate to lower-cost/free options, when available.
column42: Our mandatory size minimum is 700 eligible members.
column43: We have two standard pricing models dependent on employer preference: platform-based  and utilization-based pricing. We work with firms like Sequoia to determine which approach might be most palatable to a client based on size and whether they are self or fully insured.     Platform-Based  Our PEPM (platform based) pricing is per eligible member, per month, and includes performance guarantees on utilization of the program.  This is best for a client seeking budget predictability and/or those with populations at high risk of cancer. The PEPM fee (between $1.45 - $5 depending on employer size) includes member health assessment, development of the member's care plan, support for getting them to complete their care plan, and high touch support to handle abnormal results follow-ups, plus a fee schedule for individual screening tests that Color can support directly, and that are billed based on utilization (e.g. at-home colorectal cancer screening using a FIT test, at-home PSA test for prostate cancer screening, at-home HPV test for cervical cancer screening, genetic testing for high risk individuals).  We define large market clients as those with a population of 20k+ eligible individuals. The PEPM rate for this population ranges from $1.45-$1.05 based on population size + $49 per at home screen (FIT, PSA, HPV) + $249 per genetic screen. We define mid-market clients as those with a population of 5k - 20k eligible individuals. The PEPM rate for this population is $1.75 + $49 per at home screen (FIT, PSA, HPV) + $249 per genetic screen. We consider how we define eligible individuals on a client by client basis. These eligibless could include either all full-time employees or all full-time employees and their dependents.   Utilization-Based  Our utilization based pricing is based on participant outcomes. This is best for a client seeking to bill claims through a health plan and is designed for a small budget investment relative to projected cost savings on cancer screening and care. This pricing model includes a simple fee schedule that is billed according to utilization of Color’s services by your employees/members — including up to four service bundles billed annually per participant. For self-insured clients, these pricing bundles can be billed directly through the plan as claims.  Annual member education & assessment: ACS-led participant education and content, including webinars, onsite education events when applicable, and in-app education for enrolled members about the importance of cancer screening and early cancer detection.  Cancer screening: for members who are determined by our clinical team to need a specific cancer screen, Color’s clinician will write an order for the appropriate test.  Genetic testing: for members determined by our clinical team to be eligible for genetic screening for hereditary cancer risk based on family and/or personal history, Color provides genetic testing, genetic counseling, and referrals to appropriate clinics and centers of excellence.  High risk & diagnosis management and support: for members determined by our clinical team to be at high risk of cancer based on family and/or personal history or who have an abnormal screening result or diagnosis that requires follow-up, Color provides more advanced clinical management.  Service Bundle - Color Fees - Billing Milestone  Annual member engagement & assessment - $50 - Billed annually based on participant enrollment and/OR ongoing engagement in program services  Cancer screening - $150 - Billed for each cancer screen completed by a participant, once screen result is made available to the participant  Genetic testing - $249 - Billed for each genetic test completed by a participant, once test result is made available to the participant  High risk & diagnosis management and support - $300 - Billed for each abnormal result or cancer diagnosis managed by Color per participant, once an abnormal result or diagnosis is made available to the participant or upon participant opting in to High Risk & Diagnosis Management and Support Services
column54: Care advocacy is available Monday through Friday from 8am-5pm in the patient’s local time zone. Color’s support line is available Monday through Friday from 6am-5pm PST and there is a call-back capability enabling individuals to reach out to Color 24/7 with any questions.
column55: Color defines customer service as providing immediate, culturally sensitive, comprehensive support to participants in our programs. Color's Care Advocates have extensive experience delivering patient-centered advocacy, education, and navigation, including strong knowledge of current research and guidelines for cancer screenings. They have deep knowledge and are experienced in navigating healthcare systems, insurance coverage, and community resources related to cancer care.  Additionally, Care Advocates are trained in delivering culturally competent care with Violet's Health Equity Platform. They are American Council on Exercise (ACE) Health Coach Certified to provide care navigation and health coaching. Although Care Advocates are not clinicians, they are critical to a patient's Care Team, ensuring participants complete their screenings and next steps. Care Advocacy can help patients with follow-up care in the following areas: - Assist participants with follow-up care with their established PCP and/or a specialist and help patients develop a PCP if they do not have one. - Coach participants to optimize their health and well-being through behavior-change science methods and lifestyle medicine principles. - Empower those struggling to realize their intentions by leveraging their unique skills, strengths, abilities, and untapped potential through behavior-change techniques. - Increase participants' understanding of insurance coverage and estimated costs.   Clinical Team - We provide clinically useful and actionable screening results - immediately linking participants to clinicians to discuss their results and next steps. We have a team of clinicians that are licensed and board certified in Internal Medicine and Family Medicine to provide care and prescribe medications in all 50 states. Our physicians are able to order screening, diagnostic imaging, and lab testing. We provide access to coaches, who support participants in their goals related to nutrition, weight loss, stress management, and more.  Genetic Counselors - Color’s Genetic Counselors are American Board of Genetic Counseling (ABGC) board-certified and licensed in U.S. states that require genetic counseling licensure. They provide unlimited education sessions to discuss cancer risk factors and screening recommendations. Color’s end-to-end genetic counseling model supports 7x higher throughput of genetic counseling than in traditional clinic settings, through purpose-built workflows designed for accessible participant use and efficient clinical interactions, allowing counselors to operate at the top of their licensure by focusing on conversations with participants instead of administrative burdens.   Our Care Advocates, Clinical Team, and Genetic Counselors are licensed/certified in all 50 states.  Cancer Connect Group leaders  - Trained peer facilitators who have experienced similar circumstances and completed Color’s extensive facilitation training; cancer survivors lead the active treatment and survivor group sessions, and current or former cancer caregivers facilitate the caregiver group sessions  - Connect participants to others in similar situations, validate the unique experiences and challenges of having cancer, and empower participants with skills and strategies that will ease their cancer care journey  - Experts in leading groups across a variety of topics and skills that impact mental health and cancer, including physical health, emotions, behaviors, relationships, and thoughts   ACS cancer information specialists  - Trained to empower participants and caregivers through supportive discussion  - Available 24/7, 365 days a year to provide cancer information and support post-diagnosis about specific cancers, treatment options, side effects, medicines, pain control, and more  - Experts in delivering high-quality cancer related information, evaluating and responding to participant needs and navigating participants to available resources   Support staff  - Cross-trained team that triages all types of participant questions with relevant experience in customer support and the health services industry  - Available to participants 7 days/week to answer general questions about the program, assist with at-home sample collection, and provide technical support  - Experts in technical problem-solving, at-home testing, and Color’s programs   The philosophies and methodologies used in Color’s approach to care include the provision of culturally sensitive, linguistically relevant and trauma-informed care. This is at the heart of Color’s mission, vision, and values. Color and all its staff acknowledge and deeply understand that different communities will have different norms, expectations, and sensitivities, and we work closely with these community partners to support our site operations and accommodate language and cultural needs.

They provide unlimited education sessions to discuss cancer risk factors and screening recommendations. Color’s end-to-end genetic counseling model supports 7x higher throughput of genetic counseling than in traditional clinic settings, through purpose-built workflows designed for accessible participant use and efficient clinical interactions, allowing counselors to operate at the top of their licensure by focusing on conversations with participants instead of administrative burdens.   Our Care Advocates, Clinical Team, and Genetic Counselors are licensed/certified in all 50 states.  Cancer Connect Group leaders  - Trained peer facilitators who have experienced similar circumstances and completed Color’s extensive facilitation training; cancer survivors lead the active treatment and survivor group sessions, and current or former cancer caregivers facilitate the caregiver group sessions  - Connect participants to others in similar situations, validate the unique experiences and challenges of having cancer, and empower participants with skills and strategies that will ease their cancer care journey  - Experts in leading groups across a variety of topics and skills that impact mental health and cancer, including physical health, emotions, behaviors, relationships, and thoughts   ACS cancer information specialists  - Trained to empower participants and caregivers through supportive discussion  - Available 24/7, 365 days a year to provide cancer information and support post-diagnosis about specific cancers, treatment options, side effects, medicines, pain control, and more  - Experts in delivering high-quality cancer related information, evaluating and responding to participant needs and navigating participants to available resources   Support staff  - Cross-trained team that triages all types of participant questions with relevant experience in customer support and the health services industry  - Available to participants 7 days/week to answer general questions about the program, assist with at-home sample collection, and provide technical support  - Experts in technical problem-solving, at-home testing, and Color’s programs   The philosophies and methodologies used in Color’s approach to care include the provision of culturally sensitive, linguistically relevant and trauma-informed care. This is at the heart of Color’s mission, vision, and values. Color and all its staff acknowledge and deeply understand that different communities will have different norms, expectations, and sensitivities, and we work closely with these community partners to support our site operations and accommodate language and cultural needs.  We have designed our solutions to simplify and reduce barriers to access for all populations. We have a depth of experience providing services and resources in priority languages (other than English), and our materials are written at an 8th grade reading level. - Language Support: Color has completed health consults in 16 non-English languages, with the capability to support up to 230 languages as required by a given population.   - Transcreation: Color has a dedicated team for transcreation, which supports the creation of content in the target language that is inspired by the source concept, but highly adapted for the language and culture where it will be used. - Reading Comprehension: We aim to make our content readable by people with an eighth-grade reading level. We avoid complex clinical terminology and technical jargon. We regularly conduct comprehension testing in multiple languages to ensure that our experiences are clear. - Identity-affirming: Our products and experiences anticipate fluidity and personal transformation. Content is intentionally written to be gender neutral, and all staff are trained on providing identity-affirming care. - Culturally Appropriate: We work closely with community organizations to reach all populations. Where appropriate, we hire directly from the communities we are serving, and we always review content and illustrations for cultural appropriateness. - Trauma-informed: We practice trauma-informed design, which means that we are aware that we may be encountering people on one of their worst days, or one of their best. We empower people through clear information and choice. This means that we use clear, simple language, we are factual and complete, and we convey clear next steps. We are contextually sensitive. - Digital Accessibility: We follow WCAG 2.0 AA standards to provide accessibility in line with Section 508, with focused consideration of people who are deaf, blind, have limited mobility, and/or have cognitive differences. For example, our tools are designed to support screen readers and other assistive devices in multiple languages. Our accessibility team regularly audits our experiences for compliance using both manual and automated testing.  In addition, Color is committed to inclusive and equitable hiring, training, and personnel management practices, both in the organization as a whole, and when making staffing or subcontracting decisions for specific projects. We're proud of our diverse workforce at Color. We come from different backgrounds with different experiences, perspectives, and areas of expertise all focused on building a model of healthcare delivery that serves everyone, everywhere. As a company, we are constantly evaluating our internal forums to be sure we are creating a flexible, supportive environment for every employee to do their best work towards our critical mission. We’ve made culture investments in Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion programming and frameworks at Color, in order to ensure the Color employee experience creates space and acknowledgement for employees of all backgrounds, perspectives, and experiences.
column65: Participant satisfaction with our care team ranges from 4.7 to 4.9 out of 5.
column67: We will follow the agreed-upon implementation and program timeline to ensure that the screening offerings awarded are available by the go live date. Color has worked with thousands of organizations, including everything from large self-insured employers and labor unions, to federal agencies and state health departments. We have experience implementing our programs at scale with a strong record of reliability and timely delivery of services through on-time and on-budget implementations.  Our implementation approach is designed to allow flexibility for custom builds tailored towards the customer’s needs. Color’s implementation team will deliver a full project implementation plan within the first 7-10 days after the contract effective date with weekly updates provided in a format accessible by Sequoia’s client. This implementation plan will comprehensively detail all aspects of the screening, preventive care options, and care navigation support set up prior to the Go-Live date. Including the following: 1. Identification, timing, and assignment of significant responsibilities and tasks; 2. Identification and timing of deliverables and milestones; 3. Names and titles of key implementation staff; 4. Identification and timing of Sequoia’s client’s responsibilities; 5. Data requirements (indicate type and format of data required); 6. Identification and timing for the testing, acceptance and certification of exchange of data between Color and Sequoia’s client 7. Participant communications and their timing; 8. Schedule of in-person meetings and conference calls with the State; and 9. Transition requirements  Color has designed the implementation of the program to be easy for Sequoia’s client, and low overhead. We only need three things from Sequoia’s client to get started: 1) an eligibility file, 2) sharing the benefits guide so we can coordinate with relevant benefits and support direct referrals through our Care Advocates, 3) discuss and review our communication and employee onboarding plan to tailor it to the client's unique population and communication preferences. We ask the client's main POC to plan for only 3-4 45-min meetings ahead of launch that we will use to cover the three components we need and walk them through what to expect. Besides our main client contact, we'd ask that the client's technical POC responsible for eligibility file generation joins one of those meeting to discuss process for sharing and updating the client's eligibility file with Color. Following the launch, we typically set up bi-weekly or monthly check-ins with our main POC as appropriate to track program outcomes and metrics, and we also set up an Executive Business Review twice a year with the client's POC, their manager and executive leaders, that Color's executive leaders also attend.  All programs at Color include a robust implementation plan, a regular cadence to review program status and quickly resolve any issues that may arise. Once awarded, we will stand up a team of dedicated resources to support the program and its success for Sequoia’s client. This team will be responsible for all of the functions outlined and managing deliverables, and will be led by a Project Coordinator that will liaise between Color, Sequoia’s client, and any additional partners of the client. The individual we anticipate to assign is:   Steph Wolfram (Project Coordinator) will act as the main point of contact for the overall program, including ongoing meetings and status updates. Steph reports to Caroline Romanoff, Director of Client Services, and will also assume the role of Implementation Lead to oversee the launch, planning, execution, training, and onboarding of the program. We recommend having a standing meeting twice a week throughout implementation. Steph has over 11 years of experience launching and running programs across multiple industries. During her time at Color, she has worked on numerous healthcare offerings including launching three state-wide telehealth Covid-19 treatments programs, managing the logistics flow for a state-wide Covid-19 testing program responsible for resulting over 31,000 tests per week, and supporting over 3,700 vaccination clinics and providers.
column73: Generally at least ninety (90) days, though depending on the specific program Color can work with partners on a contract by contract basis.
column74: We know that getting employees to engage is paramount to the success of any preventive care program, so Color’s engagement approach is core to our program implementation. Through nearly 10 years of learned experience, we’ve developed a multi-faceted approach to engagement that drives results - seeing on average 4x higher utilization with Color versus average utilization in other wellness programs in the past for our preventive care programs.  We start by engaging individuals where they live and work to drive top-of-funnel awareness and engagement. We know that one size does not fit all, so our team works to tailor communications in a way that resonates for the employees, building trust from the get-go. For example: for field-laborer populations, we often work with the notion that spouses are the ones driving health decisions, so educating  them is part of our core engagement. We heavily focus on educational collateral (for example, pieces that help employees understand what genetic testing could tell them), to build curiosity and clearly communicate value in participation.  To continue to educate employees on opportunities and benefits of participation, we use digital and at-home mailers signed by trusted leadership, payroll stuffers, incentive programs, and even go onsite to health fairs or training centers to educate and support employees in person. Our engagement strategy continues throughout the year. For example, Color provides a monthly cancer awareness programming package - inclusive of flyers, webinars, email templates, and more to get the word out to your employees.   Another key to success is getting employees to take awareness a step further into action. Our care team, including clinicians, genetic counselors, and care advocates, work with each employee to help them understand their results, personalize screening guidelines, and help answer any questions so that they feel empowered by what they’ve learned to take control of their health.
column79: Color considers two primary verticals when thinking about increasing cultural diversity in the workforce; using a broad range of resources to attract talent and building an inclusive culture and hiring process. In the last few years, we have:  Talent Attraction: - Partnered with several external associations to increase and extend our reach: Epha, Out-of-Pocket, Techqueria, National Hispanic Medical Association, National Medical Association, and Circa. - Launched several Fellowship and Apprentice Programs focused on hiring non-traditional and underrepresented backgrounds: 3 Product Design Fellows, 2 Lab Operations Specialists through Emerson Collective, 2 Genetic Counselor Summer Scholars. - Launched an internal mobility process and guidelines to allow employees to continue developing their skills and careers and transfer to a different role and team. - Increased our passive outreach to female candidates by 16% (41 to 57%)  Inclusive Process: - Launched company-wide interviewer training. Trained over 400 employees on subjects including unconscious bias and how to write constructive feedback. - Launched company-wide hiring manager training. Trained over 30 hiring managers on subjects including unconscious bias and making inclusive decisions. - Established and launched an accommodation process, email, and phone number for candidates. - Added and included EEO tagline on all of our job posts.  We're proud of our diverse workforce at Color. We come from different backgrounds with different experiences, perspectives, and areas of expertise all focused on building a model of healthcare delivery that serves everyone, everywhere.  As a company, we are constantly evaluating our internal forums to be sure we are creating a flexible, supportive environment for every employee to do their best work towards our critical mission. We’ve made culture investments in Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion programming and frameworks at Color, in order to ensure the Color employee experience creates space and acknowledgement for employees of all backgrounds, perspectives, and experiences.   At Color, the value of DEI is integrated into our business model and is supported by our management team. We have a robust network of self-directed Employee Resource Groups that are provided on-going support from the DEI team and the People team for events, programming, professional development and training.  Employee Resource Groups are a key way to strengthen our culture, support employees, and foster increased engagement which includes an increasing number of remote and hybrid employees. ERGs are an extension of the Color DEI team, providing valuable feedback, unique perspectives, and insights that benefit both internal employees and external customers.   DEI Projects and initiatives in partnership with ERGs this year include: - Mentoring program  - Speaker series focused on professional development  - Identify and resolve accessibility issues for disabled employees - Recruitment of key talent from underrepresented groups - Company-wide DEI programming to increase cultural competency - Company-sponsored tech grant for women and gender diverse employees - Support and tools for working parents - Mental health awareness  Career growth fellowship-style programs being maintained or run by various Color teams in the coming year:  - Color GC Programs (GC Summer Scholars and GC Immersive) - Emerson Collective FirstGen Internship Program - NGS Lab CGMBS Training Program
column82: Color has a flexible eligibility process to ensure we meet the needs of each unique organization and to ensure an easy sign up process for eligible participants. From the organization, we will need to know who is eligible (employees and/or partners and/or dependents 18+; all employees or just health plan participants, etc.) and key verifiable information about those participants to allow them to sign up and access the benefit.   Currently we most often see two types of eligibility factors: - Demographic identifier (First Name, Last Name, DOB, Zip Code) OR - Other identifiers (i.e. email, employee ID, etc.)  During implementation, Color's eligibility experts will work with you and your data teams to identify the most inclusive and simplest way to pull eligibility. Color is happy to provide a data specification document so that your team can simply pull the required fields from your internal systems, or we can work with your team to pull the data and reformat on our end.   Collecting network coverage depends on the eligible population.  If all eligible participants are part of the same overall plan, we would collect that core information upfront and build it into our benefits routing and in-network/out of network considerations to ensure continuity of care.  If you have several populations with varying coverage options, we would work with your team to best identify a way to collect that information on an individual basis. We would also collect other benefit information during implementation to ensure that we are routing your employees to other relevant benefits (providing warm hand offs to those benefits as appropriate).
column91: Color supports Single Sign-On using the SAML 2.0 protocol. We also follow WCAG 2.0 AA standards to provide accessibility in line with Section 508, with focused consideration of people who are deaf, blind, have limited mobility, and/or have cognitive differences. For example, our tools are designed to support screen readers and other assistive devices in multiple languages. Our accessibility team regularly audits our experiences for compliance using both manual and automated testing.
column92: Color will provide Sequoia’s client with real-time HIPAA compliant aggregate dashboards to authorized program administrators to track screening and program participation metrics. We can also provide a comprehensive dashboard that combines all aggregate dashboards of Sequoia’s clients. Color is well versed in population health reporting, with geographic or demographic views of risk, guideline compliance, and other critical population health metrics. All of Color’s reports containing PHI are HIPPA compliant and will only be shared with authorized users at the direction of Sequoia’s client. Through the real-time aggregate dashboards, Sequoia’s client will have full insight into high level program data such as the number of people who have engaged, how they have engaged, positivity results, and how Color has engaged them to take action on their results.
column101: We are excited to partner with Sequoia’s client to support all of your employees’ needs related to Cancer Prevention & Screening. Color’s program combines four key elements: - Assess and educate each member about their cancer risk to drive awareness and action - Remove the complexities of screening to close the gap in screening adherence - Empower the right preventive behaviors, knowing more than 4 in 10 cancers are linked to modifiable risk factors - Provide dedicated support and resources in appropriate follow-on care  Assess and Educate about Risk - Personalized risk assessment and recommendations, based on USPSTF, American Cancer Society (ACS), and National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines. For populations at increased risk due to occupational/environmental exposure (e.g., firefighters), Color’s Scientific and Medical Affairs team will partner with your Medical Director to develop and implement custom screening protocols - Gaps in care identification and action plans, adjusted to individual risk to close screening and prevention gaps  - Educational programming about cancer prevention, available in-product and through live webinars. Cover topics about awareness and behaviors that address modifiable risk factors, e.g., “5 warning signs of breast cancer” - At-home clinical genetic testing for individuals at high risk of cancer. Test analyzes genes associated with Hereditary Breast & Ovarian Cancer (BRCA 1/2) and Lynch Syndrome, which is associated with increased risk of colorectal and uterine cancer, primarily - Unlimited 1:1 education sessions with board-certified Genetic Counselors to discuss cancer risk factors and screening recommendations  Remove Complexities of Screening - At-home cancer screening: innovative, easy-to-use at-home kits for HPV (cervical), PSA (prostate), and FIT (colorectal) cancer screening. Complete with clear instructions, phone & web-based support, and all supplies/shipping materials to collect a sample in minutes - Unlimited access to on-demand consultations with licensed clinicians to order tests, review test results, generate care plans, and answer clinical questions. Clinicians follow-up promptly on all abnormal test results to ensure next steps are taken and questions are answered - Dedicated Care Advocates to help find closest and most timely availabilities for in-person appointments (e.g., mammogram) with in-network providers. Navigate referrals and follow-ups, insurance coverage, and other support with screenings  Deliver the Right Preventative Interventions - Coaching to address modifiable risk factors for cancer.. Coaches are all American Council on Exercise (ACE) Health Coach Certified and trained to help patients increase their awareness and capacity for change following behavior-change science methods and lifestyle medicine principles. - Smoking cessation support, including medications prescribed (as appropriate) by licensed providers and smoking cessation support covered in coaching sessions  Support in Appropriate Follow-on Care - Group based mental health programs to support those with a new diagnosis, caregivers of people undergoing treatment, and survivors of cancer - High-touch, proactive post-diagnosis support from Care Advocates and Color clinicians for all participants facing a diagnosis - Patient education on available benefits, resources, and diagnosis and treatment options - Enrollment in relevant employer-sponsored programs - Direct coordination with Color clinicians and PCPs, oncologists, and/or second opinion referrals
column103: The ERISA obligations lie with the employer, however, Color will work with any prospective employer to provide information for the employer’s written Summary Plan Description (“SPD”), Form 5500, and other materials required under ERISA.
column106: For employers with more than 20 employees, an employer’s offering of the Color Cancer Screening & Prevention program would likely be subject to COBRA.   Color can work with the employer to keep former employees on an employer’s group account while they are on COBRA continuation coverage. The employer will pay the regular fee as if the former employee was still an active employee, and the employer can work with its COBRA administrator to collect a COBRA premium from the former employee, if desired. Color can also work with employers on additional options.

column29: Fetch protects over 400,000 pets and over the years we've had several thousand policyholders enroll via our partnership with Sequoia
column40: Here is a link to our brand video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kr6WvbtEap4  Our mission is to help pet parents give their pets a longer, healthier life. That’s why Fetch offers the most comprehensive health insurance coverage for cats and dogs in the U.S. and Canada—covering what other providers don’t or charge extra for. And that’s important because 1 in 3 pets need unexpected veterinary care each year. With Fetch accident and illness insurance, everything from online and emergency vet visits to name-brand prescription medications is covered, so you can protect your pet and your wallet. And when you add Fetch Wellness you'll save up to an additional $735 a year on the routine and preventive care that keeps your pets healthy.   With clinical insights from top vets and groundbreaking new technologies, Fetch Pet Insurance empowers you to enjoy more good days with your pet.   Discover the Fetch Health Forecast — our latest innovation to predict and protect your dog’s future health. Using AI, 180 million data points, insights from 800,000 dogs and top veterinarians, this technology generates a personalized report for your dog. This is the latest way Fetch is helping you give your pet a longer, healthier life.   Fetch Pet Insurance is also dedicated to giving back. That’s why we support Project Street Vet — a nonprofit that provides free veterinary care to the pets of people experiencing homelessness. Plus, Fetch supports life-saving animal adoption shelters across America.   Fetch is a leading pet wellness company dedicated to helping you give your pet a longer, happier healthier life. Long live love.
column43: Fetch’s pricing model is a highly sophisticated multivariate pricing model honed from 15+ years of data. We accurately price using a variety of pricing factors, primarily breed age and location (zip code) allowing us to provide pet parents with the best possible price.  Unlike our competitors, we do not subsidize across ages and breeds and most competitors do not differentiate as significantly across breeds and ages. Instead, they allow subsidies to be earned/spent across age bands.

column40: •Global - Wherever your employees or their families are, we’re there. Grayce has coverage on six continents, in every time zone and capabilities for 250+ languages. We can support multinational employers, as well as domestic companies whose employees have family members in other countries.  •Robust Technology Platform combined with Dedicated One-on-One Concierge Services Team - We provide a complete solution for the widest range of care challenges. From daily needs (e.g., parents needing back-up childcare) to complex care (e.g., employees caring for a loved one with cancer) and everything in between, through a combination of rich and personalized technology with dedicated one-on-one concierge support, we address the root causes that impact caregiver well-being and productivity—the emotional stress and relationship duress, the uncertainty (what to do, where to turn) and the time intensity of the role. Grayce Care Partners are trained to look at the big picture and anticipate needs. These master’s-level experts with health care and caregiver experience, create care plans that consider all aspects of the family situation, integrating medical, mental, social, legal and financial solutions. Then they do the legwork that enables the employee to stay focused on work and other family priorities. In fact, 98% of employees who used Grayce said that Grayce saved them time–from one day to four workweeks.   •Ability to Increase Utilization of Employer’s Benefits Ecosystem - The Grayce platform increases utilization of all your company benefits. We give employees one place to see all programs and resources available to them (medical, mental health, wellness and more). Grayce Care Partners look at all aspects of a caregiver’s situation and help them access any benefits that would help. In a recent survey, 58% of users reported that their Care Partner helped them identify and enroll in other company benefits that improved their total health and well-being.  •Proven ROI - We can demonstrate the impact on your bottom line. We conducted an extensive client study, which showed an ROI of 6:1, as the result of reduced absenteeism and turnover and increased productivity. We leveraged this methodology to create an Economic Impact Modeler, which we can apply to your employee data to estimate real-dollar savings and ROI for your own business.    •Recruitment and Retention - You gain the added value of an incentive for recruitment and retention. Our most recent survey results showed that, because of Grayce, 85% of respondents would be more likely to stay longer at their employer and 77% said they would be more likely to recommend their employer.
column43: Grayce's standard pricing model is utilization-based, based on the number of enrolled employees per year. We can customize our pricing model based on the employer's needs and budget.
column54: In the U.S., Care Partners are available between 5:30 am EST through 11:30 pm EST, M-F. For members outside of the U.S. the times will vary in each time zone but every time zone will have 11 hours of coverage between the hours of 5:00 AM and 9:00 PM. If a member calls after hours, the Care Partner will return the call during the next business day.
column55: Customers are the foundation for any organization and we approach our customer relationships with that in mind. All Grayce’s customers receive a designated Customer Success Manager, who ensures the overall success of the Grayce program. Customer Success Managers meet with employers quarterly to share insights around program utilization, opportunities for improvement, and recommendations for broader company culture evolution. In addition, our customers have a dedicated Employee Marketing Specialist to plan and execute on a marketing / communications plan, including program promotions and marketing activities as well as having a Grayce executive sponsor who is responsible for the overall success of the partnership.
column56: Grayce Care Partners are the most highly trained, strategic professionals in the industry: •They have master’s degrees in relevant fields, such as social work, gerontology, nursing, counseling and occupational health.  •They come from leading health care organizations, where they managed both patient and caregiver needs. •Most have had caregiver experience in their personal lives. •Care Partners have a minimum of 8-10 years experience.   Because Grayce Care Partners are master’s-level professionals, we use training to provide a broad context and understanding of issues in order to enhance their advanced skills: •Onboarding for new hires–orientation to the company, role policies and procedures, data security, privacy and HIPAA compliance. •Concierge Model–As part of the onboarding process, there is a specific module on our high-touch approach to helping caregivers, including how to match parents and caregivers and make appropriate recommendations. •Quarterly Meetings–Understand trends and events that affect families, especially world events that touch employees and family members internationally •Annual Forums focused on cultural competencies and DEI Care Partners are licensed, so we support their pursuit of continuing education units to maintain licensure.   •Social Determinants of Health  Master's-level Care Partners have the training, skills and experience to identify any social determinants of health (SDOH) issue—housing, food, transportation, utilities, and personal safety. It is a natural part of what we do when we conduct consultations with caregivers. Care Partners know how to make the caregiver feel comfortable and are quick to establish a relationship of trust. They address the immediate request but also listen carefully for related or underlying issues. They are always looking at the caregiver, the loved one and the entire family holistically, and they can identify SDOH and solve issues when they are present within the caregiver’s family or with a loved one living alone. They connect with community agencies and social services to set up assistance for the loved one (and family), such as Meals on Wheels, transportation to doctor’s appointments, subsidized housing, medical care and medications, mental health services and more. Care Partners continually assess for gaps in care and services and are there to help the caregiver provide supportive care for their loved one.
column67: Implementing Grayce concierge family care services is simple and includes the following high-level steps: •Kick-off--Understanding clients expectations, requirements, culture and population needs.  •Eligibility and Security--Setting up an eligibility file and transmission method (SFTP is preferred) and completing any required security reviews by client.  •Governance--Establishing expectations for program administration, contacts, meeting frequency. •Communications--Creating effective plans to launch, build awareness of and promote Grayce services, based on best practices from client’s internal marketing communications team.  •Reporting--Understanding client’s objectives and agreeing on key performance metrics.  •Integration with client’s Benefit Ecosystem--Setting up the Grayce Marketplace, showing all employer-sponsored benefits, as well as cross-referral procedures.
column73: This depends on the contractual terms agreed to.
column74: We develop a timeline for launch communications, info session(s) and relevant communications throughout the year, including Grayce quarterly all-employee webinars. Grayce partners with clients to drive enrollment, aligning on a mutual best approach during implementation. Typical communications plans include a launch year, and year 2+ cadences.  Customers have access to Grayce's Employee Marketing Specialist to plan and execute on a marketing / communications plan, including program promotions and marketing activities.  Grayce will provide an "Employer of Choice Toolkit," at no charge, which includes:  •Monthly marketing and communications materials for client intranet and employee microsite  •Monthly new hire email campaigns and quarterly awareness campaigns  •Videos that explain Grayce's services and how to access them •Flyers and postcards  •FAQs  •Examples of care scenarios  •Employee testimonial videos  •HR / manager resources on identifying and supporting caregiving needs  •Prompt formats for executive communications / blog posts
column79: Caregiving is an equity issue, as the prevalence and load is disproportionately carried by women and people of color. The nature and impact of that additional burden varies by group and individual. On the whole, this results in inequity, financial adversity, career growth inequity, poorer access to care, and poorer health outcomes. Women and people of color comprise the majority of Grayce's membership. As an indication of our commitment to DEI to build an effective solution on behalf of our members, each of the core pillars of Grayce's member-facing product and service are led by women of color: our product, our community, and our Care Partner services.  The Grayce Care Partner model is to assume nothing, ask explicitly what the family prefers, and to advocate on behalf of those wishes. Grayce is purpose-built to remove barriers to care and address the care challenges of each individual, regardless of culture or circumstance. For populations carrying a disproportionate burden, we partner with each family and member to specifically identify ways to remove barriers to care, including addressing health literacy needs. This could often entail identifying and accessing programs and resources for which the member / care recipient qualifies, such as Medicaid, affordable housing programs, financial assistance programs for medical care, Veterans programs, other financial and care resources, transportation, etc.
column81: We can support implementations via eligibility files or domain eligibility.
column92: Our business best practice includes conducting Quarterly Business Reviews with the client's benefits manager and other key stakeholders chosen by the client. These Reviews typically cover:  •Engagement (e.g., type and number of care interactions  •Employee Demographics (e.g., age, location)  •Top 10 Employee Needs (e.g., hiring caregiver, home safety, dementia)  •Who Employees are Caring For (e.g.,parents, children, spouse, themselves) •Member Experience(survey responses related to time savings, productivity, retention, recruitment and more)  •Member Feedback (overall star rating and testimonials)  •Communications plans and events  •Relevant Case Studies  Additionally, we track engagement across all activities, including members who attend our webinars, who attend our community events, etc...
column101: Grayce provides support, guidance and direct assistance to caregivers of children, adults and seniors--anywhere in the world. Through a combination of a content-rich technology platform and person-to-person concierge support from Grayce Care Partners, we address the root causes that affect caregiver well-being and productivity—the emotional stress and relationship duress, the uncertainty (what to do, where to turn) and the time intensity of the role. We are distinguished by the skill and experience of our Care Partners, who hold master's degrees in such fields as sociology, gerontology, nursing, counseling and occupational health. They come from health care organizations and have been caregivers in their personal lives. Unlike other transactional referral or caregiver listing services, Grayce supports families through every step of their care journey, from strategizing to sourcing, vetting to implementing, and following up with the family throughout the year. Care Partners do the legwork that lets the employee stay focused on the job, other family priorities and their own health. The Grayce platform supports and complements the services of Grayce Care Partners. With insightful prompts that unlock relevant articles, trackers and organizational tools, the Grayce platform provides real-life personalized support. It enables care consultations or quick chats with Care Partners, as needs unfold. The caregiver can invite other caregivers to log-on, giving the family access to updates or participation in family meetings, facilitated by their Care Partner.

column40: RethinkFirst was founded in 2007 with a simple goal of providing scalable autism treatment tools and caregiver support to an underserved population in need.  In 2014, Rethink launched its employer solution, RethinkCare (formerly known as Rethink Benefits), and enterprise organizations across the US started to take note of the incredible tools and e-learning content available to support working parents and caregivers of developmentally challenged children. Today, the RethinkCare platform has expanded to holistically support all working parents, caregivers, and their families. RethinkCare offers three award-winning solutions to support employees in all aspects of their life, from work to home and everything in between. Our innovative solutions leverage evidence-based and clinically validated approaches to enable employees to be healthier, happier, and more successful in all areas of life.  No provider in the space offers our combination of high-tech digital resources and high tough expert support centering on neurodiversity at home and at work. Specifically, we are the only resource featuring ABA-trained experts available to all parents, regardless of their need. We are also the only resource featuring ABA-trained experts supporting both neurodivergent individuals at work and their managers, leaders, and co-workers.
column43: RethinkCare provides PEPY/PEPM pricing for a client based on their size,  desired products, and other factors.
column55: Customer service is provided via our CSM team. Additionally, we have a 24/7 help line where members can call to initiate a troubleshooting ticket where our teams will acknowledge the next business day and typically address and resolve within 24 business hours.  Members are able to contact our member services via three ways: email, online form, and telephonically. All these methods flow into a single location where trouble tickets are assigned, responded to and resolved.
column56: Yes. Our parenting consultants are BCBAs or BCBA-Ds, which means they are Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA)-trained and –certified. All parenting and workplace neurodiversity consultants have a master’s degree or higher. Our neurodiversity experts have at least 15 years of experience supporting neurodivergent individuals at work and at home. All RethinkCare experts have deep expertise in supporting individuals with developmental disabilities, such as autism and attention-deficit/hyperactive disorder (ADHD), and those who support them.
column67: We typically implement over 60 days, though we can do so on a much shorter turnaround with minimal work to the client. A typical client will onboard new users via a registration page with a unique, branded link and a join code that will be given to the client to share with their team. Should clients wish we can also build access via an SSO; in a few cases a client may prefer an exchange of eligibility files at a regular cadence via SFTP. We schedule a discussion with partner engineering team to gather information related to specs, APIs and SSO mechanisms to use for the integration. We schedule weekly calls to coordinate progress and request for test accounts to successfully verify the integration as we make progress. Our Product team creates Jira tickets with implementation tasks, and we measure the effort and include them in a sprint. Any customization for SSO integration will be discussed in kick-off call to set respective expectations.
column74: We provide a Success Toolkit of pre-built resources for use by clients to drive both adoption and utilization. Our Customer Success team builds out a roll-out plan for each enterprise client to maximize adoption in the first year and with ongoing support to ensure awareness and ongoing increases in utilization. We also send push notifications (which can be disabled) to users and prompts following course completions. We're further setting up an additional email cadence to drive existing users to interact with the platform.
column79: Cultural humility is at the core of what we do as an organization. Cultural humility emphasizes the need to prioritize the needs, goals, and lived experiences of the individuals we serve above our own. This includes in the training process and ongoing supervision and case management of our Board Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA) team and in the creation and review of our digital assets. Our Clinical Director, Dr. Angela Nelson, and her team have centuries of combined experience working with neurodiverse families and neurodivergent individuals and children. As we continue to grow our team, we prioritize hiring BCBAs living and working outside the United States (including London and Dubai) and with additional language abilities (including Spanish, French, Farsi, Mandarin, Japanese, and Somali).  In addition, our self-guided coursework supports neurodivergent individuals, and neurodiversity generally, both at home and at work. We help teach those supporting neurodivergent individuals to recognize and better support different methods of learning and communication. We provide direct, tactical guidance for neurodivergent individuals themselves on self-advocacy, communication, interviewing, performance, executive function, and more.

column91: Where clients prefer or require, we have the ability to utilize the most common SSO protocols (including SAML and OKTA) to provide for seamless access for an employee population. This may be at an additional fee depending upon the complexity of standing up that gateway.   Most commonly, a client will select a join code and unique registration link to be used by their population. That join code can be changed at intervals determined by the client and RethinkCare. A user is required to provide the join code to register for RethinkCare. We can also require registration by client email domain or utilize an eligibility file, in which case users are authenticated against that file. User will create their own credentials during enrollment using our r egistration page customized per customer. User will receive a verification email for activating their account.
column92: RethinkCare offers reporting that can be generated on a monthly, quarterly, or yearly basis. These reports include billing and revenue reports, client outcomes reports, clinician utilization reports, and staff performance reports, among others. RethinkCare offers a user-friendly portal where organizations can access reports and data in real time as we understand that organizations have unique needs when it comes to data analysis. Our self-service portal allows you to customize your dashboards, generate reports, and export data for further analysis.
column101: Parental Success RethinkCare’s Parental Success solution empowers working parents and caregivers with the tools to raise more confident and resilient children. Employees can access thousands of on-demand e-learning sessions and speak with on-staff Board Certified Behavior Analysts to address the unique behavioral and mental health needs for their children including those who are neurodivergent (diagnosed with autism, ADHD, or other learning disabilities). Our master-and doctoral-level BCBAs work one-on-one with parents to co-create effective solutions across a broad spectrum of challenges.  Professional Resilience RethinkCare’s Professional Resilience solution helps employees worldwide be the best versions of themselves at work each day. We empower both neurotypical and neurodivergent individuals with necessary skills to grow in their careers, improve relationships and emotional intelligence, and manage stress at work. We are continuously expanding our industry-leading neurodiversity support content and expert consultation offerings to cultivate an engaged workforce and inclusive culture.  Personal Wellbeing RethinkCare’s Personal Wellbeing solution helps employees worldwide learn and apply integral skills to manage stress, anxiety, and sleep issues. Created with 85+ world-leading experts, hundreds of on-demand mindfulness and resilience training sessions empower employees to improve their emotional and physical wellbeing through meditation, positive psychology, yoga, and more.

column40: Spring Health equips employers and health plans across the globe to make mental health accessible and achievable. We use clinically validated machine learning, what we call Precision Mental Healthcare, to deliver optimal care — digital CBT, coaching, therapy, medication management, or a combination of all four. We are on a mission to eliminate every barrier to mental health. Our member-centric approach and experience has led to rapid adoption among large employers and year-over-year growth of 270%. We believe the following differentiators demonstrate our passion for caring the most about mental healthcare.  - Our clinically validated technology, Precision Mental Healthcare, accurately predicts the right treatment that will work for each member’s mental health care journey. The technology eliminates ineffective treatment, speeds up recovery time by 8 weeks, and helps over 86% of members fully recover. Important to note, that our technology is clinically validated and peer-reviewed by trusted medical publications, including JAMA, The Lancet, American Psychiatric Association (APA).  - A sophisticated Care Support program strives to provide a transformative member and provider experience through timely resolution, empathy, and professionalism. The team’s primary responsibilities include responding to real-time member and clinician inquiries and needs such as (but not limited to) scheduling, triaging prescription refill requests, executing patient documentation and resource items, and troubleshooting platform access issues. Also, whenever needed, each member has access to a Care Navigator, licensed therapists schooled, trained, and experienced working with members of all conditions on the mental health spectrum, from lightweight mild issues (work-life and resiliency) to extremely clinical and severe (substance use and suicidal ideation). Finally, this coordinated and collaborative approach is reflected in our comprehensive platform, Compass, an EHR developed with and for our providers.  - We curate our provider network with a priority on diversity, availability, and evidence and measurement-based treatment. Our network comprises many ethnic and racial backgrounds and specialties to create an inclusive environment to seek care. Our network is 3x the national average for providers who identify as BIPOC, 6x the national average for providers who identify as Black, and 2x the national average for providers who identify as Asian. We ensure providers are available during traditional and non-traditional hours (before/after work and on weekends) and the average time to first appointment is <2 days. We align with providers who are committed to evidence-based treatment and continuous measurement.  - Our proprietary technology, Candela, measures provider performance, in real-time, to ensure the highest quality network and care for members. Higher-quality care means a shorter time to recover, drastically lowering healthcare costs. We track care across clinical metrics, such as depression and anxiety improvement, and operational metrics, such as time commitment to Spring Health’s customers and member experience. We align higher, data-proven, quality to payment as financial incentives for higher-performing providers and see our solution as the first pay-for-performance network in mental health care.  - We have developed an electronic health record, integrated by all our providers, called Compass. The Compass platform supports delivering the most clinically and financially effective mental healthcare. Providers receive data that shows and predicts member progress toward an outcome. This allows the provider to give more accurate diagnoses, modify treatment plans in real time, and improve patient outcomes faster. The tools available through Compass make it easier for therapists to use outcome measures, reduce administrative burden and burnout, and enable effective collaboration by providing a well-designed EHR workflow. This coordinated and collaborative approach supports the entire Spring Health Care Team — from clinicians to support staff — to deliver smarter and faster mental healthcare. Coaches will be fully incorporated into Compass in Q1 2024.  - Spring Health delivers financial ROI in several ways. The Validation Institute recently certified Spring Health as the first and only comprehensive mental health solution to show net savings for customers, lowering total health plan spend by $2,430 per participant in the first six months of engagement. Access to high-quality mental health providers more than paid for itself; for every $1.00 invested in Spring Health, customers saved $2.20 on their health plan spend. Those savings increased to $4.10 when accounting for reduced absenteeism (22%) and turnover (12%).  - Spring Health delivers the most accurate and transparent pricing in the market, which functions to secure a client’s investment with its comprehensive mental health partner. We are committed to cost transparency in several unique ways, including a standardized national rate card. No matter where employees are located or what type of provider they see, the rate remains the same. Furthermore, with zero hidden fees, our clients are never surprised by unexpected costs (technology, intersession fees, etc.), which often get tacked onto our competitors’ invoices. We have also recently refined our ROI methodology to create more accurate pricing and ROI projections by incorporating data-backed assumptions and organizational-specific metrics.
column43: Our pricing structure is flexible. We offer 2 primary pricing options. Both include unlimited Care Navigation via licensed therapists and unlimited platform access (initial assessment based on an IP-protected, science-based algorithm, personalized treatment plan, online provider scheduling, and digital CBT exercises). However, the way employer-sponsored sessions are billed differs:  - Bundled Model: Employer-sponsored provider visits billed as a PEPM, regardless of utilization (includes all Spring Health core services and bundled pre-paid therapy/coaching sessions).  - Direct Bill Fee-for-Service: Employer pays PEPM for all Spring Health core services. Therapy sessions are billed monthly directly to you, based on utilization.  We deliver the most accurate and transparent pricing in the market, which functions to secure a client’s investment with its comprehensive mental health partner. We maintain our commitment to cost transparency with our standardized national rate card. The rate remains the same regardless of where members are located or what type of provider they see. Unlike competitors, we also have no hidden fees or unexpected costs for employers and partners (technology, intersession fees, etc.).
column54: Our service hours are as follows: Care Support is available 8 a.m. - 11 p.m. EST M-F by telephone, live chat, and email.  Care Navigation is available 8 a.m. - 11 p.m. EST M-F by telephone and email  Crisis Support is available 24/7/365.
column55: Our customer service model is based on a customer-first approach. Spring Health provides an account manager (Customer Success Manager), who will continue to serve as your single point of contact and engagement for other areas of our organization. We will continue to bring our entire team to support you, including our clinical leadership, data science, marketing, and more as needed. Your Customer Success Manager will continue to lead all reporting presentations, proactively reaching out and recommending communication suggestions, informing you of new product developments, and supporting your team's efforts in improving mental health across your clients' population.  Your Customer Success Manager will:  - Proactively reach out to your team to make communications suggestions, inform you of new product developments, and support your team’s efforts in improving mental health across your clients' population - Prepare and lead all reporting activities and business reviews - Provide immediate insight regarding time-sensitive data - Be the point of contact for other benefit vendors within your ecosystem, supporting integrations or other services that would improve the Spring Health experience for members - Answer any questions or fulfill any requests from your team
column56: Our therapist and physician network comprises both licensed therapists (psychotherapy) and psychiatrists (medication management), The providers in the Spring Health network are also fully licensed clinicians with at least a master's degree, are state-licensed to practice independently, have 3 years of experience post-licensure, and meet minimum malpractice requirements.   Types of therapists in our network: LCSW, LMFT, LPC, LPA, ANP, PhD, PsyD Types of physicians in our network: MDs, DOs.  All Care Navigators at Spring Health are master's level clinicians of varying licenses; LMFT, LCSW, and LPCs.   The non-clinical staff (coaches) qualifications and training requirements include:  Graduates of an ICF-accredited coaching training program, ICF-credentialed coach (ACC, MCC, PCC), or National Board Certified Minimum of 100 hours of post-training coaching experience Adhere to the Ethical Framework for Technology-delivered Coaching Comfortable with technology and telehealth competent Committed to quality care
column67: Spring Health's implementation plan is efficient and a light lift for our clients. We require an eligibility file and take time to discuss and create customized communication pieces to resonate with your members. We request 60-90 days for implementation but can also accommodate more quickly when required.  From Day 1, you will work with a designated team that will support the successful implementation of the Spring Health program and our ongoing partnership. Spring Health will provide an account manager (Customer Success Manager), who will serve as your single point of contact and engagement point in other areas of our organization. We will bring our entire team to support you, including our clinical leadership, data science, marketing, and more as needed. Your Customer Success Manager will also lead all reporting presentations, proactively reach out and recommend communication suggestions, inform you of new product developments, and support your team's efforts in improving mental health across your member population.   During implementation, you will also work closely with the assigned implementation manager. Your Implementation Manager and Customer Success Manager oversee all implementation work streams so that implementation of the Spring Health program is a guided low-lift experience for you. We set up a weekly cadence of meetings to review progress, status, open action items, and any issues/risks with mitigation strategies. We have a few main work streams, including legal and security agreement execution, eligibility file production readiness, Spring Health operational and technology deployment, communications and engagement strategy, and benefit vendor integrations. We have a governing project artifact that is used to track all items and is the source of truth for all work streams.
